Dwayne Johnson, also known by his professional stage name "The Rock," is a multi-talented American actor, professional wrestler, businessman, and former professional wrestler. He was born on May 2, 1972, in Hayward, California, to a Jamaican immigrant father and a Filipino mother.

Raised by his single mother, Johnson displayed an athletic ability from a young age, participating in a variety of sports like football, wrestling, and track and field. In high school, Johnson attended Berkeley High School, where he excelled both in academics and sports. He attended the University of Miami for two years on a football scholarship, but due to a severe knee injury, he had to give up his football career.

Determined to pursue a different path, Johnson relocated to Texas and joined a professional wrestling organization called World Class Championship Wrestling, where he learned the ropes and began honing his skills as a wrestler. His natural charisma and athleticism earned him an immediate popularity, and in 1995, he signed with the World Wrestling Federation (now known as WWE).

He also made headlines by transitioning into film, making his acting debut in the movie "The Scorpion King" in 2002. Since then, he has appeared in numerous blockbuster films such as "The Game Plan," "Snakes on a Plane," "San Andreas," "Race to Witch Mountain," and most recently, "Jumanji: The Next Level."

Beyond his entertainment career, Dwayne Johnson is a passionate advocate for various charitable causes, including Hurricane Sandy relief efforts, cancer awareness, and military support. He has founded his own production company, Seven Bucks Productions, and through it, he is producing a range of films and television series.

Dwayne Johnson's legacy as a wrestler, actor, and philanthropist has left an indelible mark on the world, making him one of the most beloved and successful entertainment icons of our time.

Sometimes known as 'The Rock', Dwayne Douglas Johnson is an American professional wrestler, actor, and entrepreneur who rose to fame during the late 1990s and early 2000s. Born on May 2, 1972, in Hayward, California, Dwayne was raised in a single-parent household by his mother, Jacklyn Eleanor Scantlin, a waitress.

Dwayne grew up as a devoted fan of professional wrestling, particularly inspired by the legendary "Hulk Hogan." In 1996, he made his debut in the world of professional wrestling by signing with the World Wrestling Federation (WWF). Under his ring name, "Rocky Maivia," he quickly gained popularity among fans for his charismatic persona, formidable strength, and catchphrase, "It's Not a Game, It's a Lifestyle."

Dwayne's charisma and athleticism soon led him to headline the "Monday Night Wars" between WWF and World Championship Wrestling (WCW). His most notable moments in wrestling include becoming the first African-American WWF World Heavyweight Champion in 1998, the first WWF Champion to unify the company's heavyweight titles in 2002, and his multiple appearances at WrestleMania.

In 2004, Dwayne Johnson made the transition to Hollywood and successfully transitioned into an action movie star, with his first major film being "The Scorpion King." He quickly became a bankable superstar, starring in blockbuster films such as "Fast & Furious," "Race 2," "Hercules," and the "Moana" trilogy, among others. Dwayne's ability to portray both tough, stoic roles and vulnerable, emotional characters has earned him an ever-growing fan base, resulting in box office hits like "Furious 7," "Jumanji: The Next Level," and "Skyscraper."

Beyond his acting career, Dwayne Johnson is a passionate entrepreneur, owning multiple successful businesses, including the D-Wayne's World gym franchise, Barbell Guy, and his own line of fitness clothing.
